ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lectures are also recorded.
One-on-one zoom meetings
Live virtual lectures and live office hours
Some pre-recorded lectures.
This class was mostly live virtual lectures, with a few recorded lectures to expand on concepts covered in class.
Office hours, a few extra lectures
All lectures were also recorded and made available on Panopto for later viewing/rewatching.
I attended lecture for the first 1/3 of the course. For the rest of the lectures I had to watch them after being posted as recorded lectures due to personal difficulties.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge of fluid mechanics, following a rather unconventional approach: we spent quite a bit of time learning purely conceptual stuff at the beginning of the semester. Then, at about mid-semester, we started learning how this conceptual stuff could be used in applications. I feel like we started with the hardest stuff, but once we had that strong conceptual foundation, everything followed nicely from there.

All the essential topics of fluid mechanics: couette flow, the Navier Stokes equations, tensors, stress, torque, flow analysis, the Bernoilli equation, hydrostatics, creeping flow, lubrication flow, boundary layer flow, inviscid flow, etc.

Also developed lots of mathematical skills: vector math, tensors, looking at coordinate systems other than cartesian, similarity solutions, partial and ordinary differential equations, multivariable calculus, etc.
Learned about fluid mechanics and problem solving skills
An intensive overview of fluids and transport problems.
In this class, I developed my math and physics skills for fluid mechanics, most importantly my differential equation and multivariable calculus skills. I also developed my problem-solving skills.
I learned about fluid statics, balance equations on mass and momentum, stress as momentum flux, the Navier-Stokes equations for incompressible fluids, macroscopic balances, and boundary layer theory.
This course is a blend of physics, high-level calculus, and engineering intuition. Required brushing up on previous classes and even learning new math material.
I reinforced my abilities to think critically about engineering principles and apply them in the real world.

This course teaches you how to problem solve and think like an engineer. Additionally, it gives an overview of fluid mechanics including stresses and shear stresses, tensors, fluid statics, macroscopic balances, the Bernoulli equation, the Navier Stokes equations, and boundary layer theory.
Heavy development of intuition of physical concepts, math skills, and problem-solving ability

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: the lectures are well structured and you will actually learn a lot in 1hour15. The course is fairly small and mostly everyone was very engaged. The grading is fair. 

Weaknesses: the homework problems don't always follow from what we learned in class. Sometimes, the pace is too fast and your brain will feel like mush.

Strengths
-VANDERLICK!!! BEST PROFESSOR EVER
-Lots of help offered
-Very fair grading scheme
-interesting material
-manageable workload
Weaknesses:
-TA could have been better prepared

I wish there were some sort of class notes or textbook that I could've read that followed the class. I easily got lost in lectures and in most classes I would turn to the textbook to learn the material, but this class didn't really follow a textbook and no class notes were provided. Overall, I felt like learning the material was hard for me because I felt like I didn't have the resources to learn the material. Even though the lectures were recorded, rewatching the lectures didn't help me better understand the material. I went to office hours but was often so confused I didn't know what I didn't know and what questions to ask. The one thing that I found very helpful in learning the material were the  3-4 review sessions that were held after the first exam in preparation for the mulligan. Those review sessions really helped me learn the material, so I wish there were these type of review sessions before every test.

The strength of this class is Professor Vanderlick. This class is just one of the hardest classes at Yale, and she made it much less stressful than I would have walked in expecting. She demands very high engagement with the class, but knows how to gauge the audience well and answer our questions to the best capacity. The weakness of this class is probably just the fact that the course materials take up most of the time of your semester, and that there is little handout material to work on (i.e. you have to watch recorded lectures if you miss the class). I would say that's not really much of a weakness, because honestly if you do not pay enough attention to Fluids you just will not get it. The class's grading scheme might seem complicated at first, but Professor Vanderlick is accommodating in a way that it is mainly up to you to put in the work.

This course emphasizing the Fluid Mechanics material that is relevant to chemical engineers and does not spend much time on the material that is more important mechanical engineers. The course being structured in this way was great.
This course is really well taught by Professor Vanderlick, and this is the second class that I have had with her.

Strengths: Vanderlick is an incredible professor. A great lecturer, cares about her students, cant recommend her enough.
Weaknesses: its very much a class where youre thrown in and you just have to figure out how to swim. Can be overwhelming at times, but definitely builds problem-solving skills.

Strengths: small class size (it's a class geared toward chemical engineering students specifically, so these are the students who will be in many of your other classes for junior and senior year)
Weaknesses: lectures sometimes lacked structure; example problems were almost never solved all the way through; exam grading is a bit subjective since she doesn't grade using points; course grade is determined solely from average of exams

The supplementary material (swiffers, clarification videos) is a big plus for this course because they ensure students are thinking properly about the material. One weakness I would point out is the speed at which material is presented. Some material is taught thoroughly with examples while other material is only mentioned yet still appears on the homework assignments.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Forcing the students to keep their video on definitely improved engagement and bonding in the class. Everyone was more focused during class, and everyone knew each other on a name basis. 

In terms of what could be improved, adding sessions to get help on homework or to cooperate on homework might be helpful.
It was perfect!
I thought the virtual lectures mimics in person lectures well

Professor Vanderlick made serious attempts to make herself available, with 3 different office hours and somewhat flexible deadlines in light of other Chemical Engineering courses' exams. There really is not much to improve.

Professor Vanderlick really made the lectures interesting. She would call on us to answer questions. While I would have preferred to take the class in person, Professor Vanderlick did really well with the online format.
Recording lectures is a godsend and should always be done.
Lectures were held synchronously, but were also recorded.
All practices succeeded.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you're a chemical engineer, I would definitely recommend taking this class over the mechanical engineering fluid mechanics.

I would ABSOLUTELY recommend it, especially if you're deciding between the mechanical and chemical fluid dynamics. Definitely pick this one. Vanderlick is the absolute best. She offers so much help and really wants all her students to succeed, getting everyone who is willing to put in the work to an A. She also has a very fair grading system. 

It's really difficult material, but super interesting. Having Vanderlick as a professor willi really inspire you to find the topic more interesting than you maybe initially thought.
Only if you are interested in fluid mechanics

Yes but only if you are in Mechanical/Chemical/Environmental Engineering. I know that MechEs have their own version, but this is just hands down much better of a course than what I assume their course is like. If you are not those Engineering majors, maybe if you would like to challenge yourself; I wouldn't really expect anyone except maybe Physics students to consider the course.

100%. If you're ChemE, you won't regret taking this course with Professor Vanderlick. The course is challenging, but Professor Vanderlick will make sure that you have all of the resources you need to be successful in this course. Definitely a large time commitment, but you will learn a lot and the some of the material is really interesting.
I would recommend this course to another student, although it isn't really necessary unless the student is studying engineering.
Yes! Fluids is a meh topic and its easy to get lost in the weeds, but any class with Vanderlick is a good time.
Take this course if you are a chemical engineering major in need of fulfilling major requirements.
Recommend if you need it for your major. Otherwise think twice because it is a very difficult course. It's well taught nonetheless.

For engineering majors, this course is one of the hardest but taking it will give you a great understanding of what it means to be an engineer. However, it is definitely very challenging and if you want to get the most out of it you need to dedicate a lot of your time and effort. To get a sense of how much time and energy you need to put in, I was told that this course "took the sparkle out of my eyes". If you don't commit yourself fully, you are wasting your time because you will still have to put in a lot of work to get a decent grade.
